Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Mechanics of the Axoneme in Genetically-Modified Flagella

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to measure the mechanical properties and active processes that produce propulsive motion in cilia and flagella. Cilia and flagella are tiny subcellular structures (about 200 nanometers in diameter and 5-30 micrometers long) that beat regularly to propel cells or to move fluid. Cilia line the airways of the human respiratory system and beat in coordination to eliminate bacteria and particles. In this project, elastic stiffness and ability to produce force will be measured in algae flagella, which have structure and behavior very similar to human cilia. Mechanical properties will be tested in flagella with specific genetic mutations, under varying experimental conditions, to learn how the underlying structural features produce the coordinated oscillations required for effective propulsion. The novel combination of mechanics and genetics is uniquely suited to make progress on this problem.

If successful, these studies will advance our scientific understanding of cilia and flagella, and provide insight into how these systems fail in injury or disease. This improved understanding could lead to new methods for diagnosis and therapy, or ways to harvest energy from biological oscillators. More generally, these studies will clarify the coordination mechanisms which allow many independent microscopic oscillators to work together to produce macroscopic motion. The project will achieve broad impact through a partnership between Washington University (WU; a research-intensive private university) and the University of Central Oklahoma (UCO; a public institution focused on undergraduate education). Through this partnership, undergraduate students from both institutions will participate in research, enhancing the availability of such experiences to a diverse population. This award will also support educational projects in which high school and undergraduate students design large-scale, physical models of cilia and flagella. These models will illuminate the behavior of cilia and flagella while providing practical experience in electromechanical design and control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cilia and flagella are thin, flexible, microscopic structures that extend from the surface of a cell and beat rhythmically to propel the cell or move fluid. For example, cilia are responsible for clearing bacteria and particles from human airways, and flagella oscillations are responsible for sperm motility. The internal structure of cilia and flagella is well known, and it is clear that a motor protein, dynein, provides the internal force that produces bending. But how dynein molecules work together to create waves has remained a mystery. The goal of the project was to measure the mechanical properties of flagella and to understand how wavelike oscillations are produced and modulated.

In terms of intellectual merit, the stiffness of flagella was successfully determined by measuring their bending in response to very small forces. These tiny forces were produced by the action of a laser on a microscopic bead: a system known as an optical trap. During active beating, the movements of flagella were clearly affected by the viscosity of the fluid, and by the type of dynein motor proteins that were present. Using these experimental measurements in detailed mathematical models of flagella, it was found that wavelike oscillations could be caused by a mechanical instability, like the fluttering of a flag or an airplane wing. No feedback from motion to dynein activity is necessary. This theoretical model, based on experimental measurements, represents a new conceptual understanding of flagella motion, which could lead to novel biomimetic designs of artificial swimmers or microfluidic devices.

In terms of broader impact, students, both graduate and undergraduate, were involved in the project and learned research techniques at the interface of mechanical engineering, biophysics, and biology. One graduate student, Kate Wilson (female), was supported by the project and received her PhD in Mechanical Engineering. Thirteen undergraduate students (7  female, 3 under-represented minority) participated in research on the project. Six of these students were from undergraduate institutions (University of Central Oklahoma and New Mexico School of Mines) with limited research opportunities. The majority of the undergraduates attended national conferences and/or published technical papers. Thus this project provided significant benefits in terms of workforce development.  One undergraduate, Tianchen (Gary) Hu, received 2nd place nationally in the NSF-sponsored undergraduate research poster competition.  The principal investigator was recognized by his university for contributions to undergraduate research.
